PC Number: 2004-0552

Date: 2004-05-04

                     Whereas Her Majesty in right of the Province of Ontario (the “Province”) is empowered by the Public Transportation and Improvement Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. P-50, to take lands or an interest in lands without the consent of the owner for public highway purposes;


                     And whereas the Province requires certain lands in Big Grassy River Indian Reserve No. 35G described in the annexed schedule (the “lands”) for public highway purposes;


                     Therefore, Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, hereby

 

(a) pursuant to subsection 35(1) of the Indian Act, consents to the exercise by the Province of the power to take the lands without the consent of the owner, subject to the terms set out in paragraph (b); and

 

(b) pursuant to subsection 35(3) of the Indian Act, in lieu of the Province taking the lands, authorizes the transfer of administration and control of the lands to the Province, subject to the following terms:

 

(i) the taking or transfer, as the case may be, shall not include any mines or minerals, precious or base, and whether solid, liquid or gaseous, including any coal, petroleum, and any gas or gases, which may be found in, under or upon the lands save and except for sand and gravel and their extraction, on, in or under the Bridge Lands as that expression is defined in the Big Grassy First Nation River Boundary Settlement Agreement (the “Agreement”) for use within the lands;

 

(ii) the taking or transfer of the lands, as the case may be, shall be subject to a right of entry by Her Majesty in right of Canada (“Canada”), or any person acting under the authority of Canada, to enter upon the lands or any part of them to explore for and develop the mines and raise and extract the minerals and to use and enjoy every part of the lands, and their easements and privileges, for any of those purposes and every other purpose connected with them, provided that the exercise of the right of entry does not interfere with the use of the lands for the purposes set out in subparagraph (iii);

 

(iii) the lands shall not be used for any purpose other than public highway purposes, such purposes being limited to

 

(A) the public right of access to and passage over the lands as a public highway;

 

(B) the right of the Province of access to and passage over the lands for public highway purposes, which purposes shall include inspecting, maintaining, repairing and replacing the Bridge as that word is defined in the Agreement; and

 

(C) the right of the Province to construct the Replacement Bridge as that expression is defined in the Agreement and to inspect, maintain, repair and replace all or any portion of the Replacement Bridge;

 

(iv) unless required by the Province for public highway purposes or unless the Province and the Big Grassy Band (the “Band”) agree in writing, the lands shall not be used for

 

(A) poles, lines, conduits and appurtenances of a telephone system or of an information transmission system;

 

(B) pipelines for the transmission or distribution of artificial or natural gas, petroleum products, steam or hot water; or

 

(C) poles, lines, conduits and appurtenances or system for the transmission of electrical power or energy;

 

(v) if the Band proposes that the lands be put to a use referred to in subparagraph (iv), the Province shall only withold its agreement to that proposed use if the Province’s right or ability to use the lands for public highway purposes may be adversely affected by the proposed use or if there are other reasonable grounds for the Province to withold its agreement;

 

(vi) in circumstances where Canada’s agreement is required by law in order for the lands to be put to a use referred to in subparagraph (iv), the Province and the Band may seek the agreement of Canada, which agreement shall not be unreasonably witheld by Canada;

 

(vii) where in accordance with subparagraphs (iv) to (vi), the Band, the Province and Canada if its agreement is required by law, agree in writing that the lands may be used for a purpose which is not a public highway purpose, such use shall be subject to any terms, conditions, fees and charges as may be imposed by the Band, the Province and Canada, if applicable;

 

(viii) the Band shall have the right to use the waters over the lands, including the water surface, provided that the uses of the waters shall not interfere with the support or safety of the Bridge or the Replacement Bridge, or the constructing of the Replacement Bridge, or the use of the lands for public highway purposes or any other purpose agreed to by the Band, the Province and, if applicable, Canada;

 

(ix) if the lands or any part of them cease to be used for the purpose set out in subparagraph (iii), the Province shall transfer to Canada, at no cost, the administration and control of the lands or that part of them, for the purpose of returning the lands or that portion of them to reserve land for the use and benefit of the Band, as if the lands or that part of them had not passed to the Province;

 

(x) that the lands or any part of them, administration and control of which is transferred by the Province in accordance with subparagraph (ix), shall be in a satisfactory environmental condition, with such condition to be determined by the Band, the Province and Canada acting reasonably and having regard to the intention that the lands or that part of them be returned to reserve status if the lands or that part of them are in an unsatisfactory environmental condition and such condition is attributable to the presence of the Replacement Bridge, the Province shall, at its expense and in relation only to the condition or conditions attributable to the presence of the Replacement Bridge, restore the lands or that part of them to a satisfactory environmental condition prior to transferring administration and control of the lands to Canada;

 

(xi) the Province shall pay the Receiver General for Canada, prior to the taking by or transfer to the Province of the lands, as the case may be, the amount of $15,000; and

 

(xii) Canada accepts the money referred to in subparagraph (xi) as full and final satisfaction and compensation to Canada for the taking or transfer of the lands, as the case may be, by or to the Province.
